radare2-cutter-part-2-analysing-a-basic-.navtitle: Cutter Part 2: Analysing a Basic Program
radare2-cutter-part-2-analysing-a-basic-.title: Introduction to Reverse Engineering with radare2 Cutter - Part 2: Analysing a Basic Program
radare2-cutter-part-2-analysing-a-basic-.longdesc: Analysing a basic program using static analysis in radare2 Cutter.
radare2-cutter-part-2-analysing-a-basic-.shortdesc: Analysing a basic program using radare2 Cutter.
radare2-cutter-part-2-analysing-a-basic-.snippet:
I have put together a basic program that takes a number as an input, and outputs whether the number is odd or even.

Enter a Number (or q to quit): 2
2 is even.
Enter a Number (or q to quit): 1
1 is odd.
Enter a Number (or q to quit): 25
25 is odd.
Enter a Number (or q to quit): hello
Invalid Input
Enter a Number (or q to quit): q

booting-a-physical-windows-10-disk-using.navtitle: VirtualBox Physical Windows 10 Disk on Linux
booting-a-physical-windows-10-disk-using.title: Booting a Physical Windows 10 Disk Using VirtualBox on Linux
booting-a-physical-windows-10-disk-using.longdesc: Configuring VirtualBox on Linux to boot a physical Windows 10 disk connected via SATA or USB.
booting-a-physical-windows-10-disk-using.shortdesc: Configuring VirtualBox on Linux to boot a physical Windows 10 disk.
booting-a-physical-windows-10-disk-using.snippet: I recently acquired a computer with an OEM/factory-imaged Windows 10 disk inside. Straight away I took the disk out and replaced it with a Linux SSD, however since I don't own any other Windows systems, this will come in useful for testing my website for browser compatibility in Internet Explorer and Edge. I have put the Windows 10 disk in a USB SATA drive enclosure, and configured VirtualBox to be able to boot the raw disk.

radare2-cutter-part-1-key-terminology-an.navtitle: Cutter Part 1: Key Terminology and Overview
radare2-cutter-part-1-key-terminology-an.title: Introduction to Reverse Engineering with radare2 Cutter - Part 1: Key Terminology and Overview
radare2-cutter-part-1-key-terminology-an.longdesc: An overview of some key reverse engineering terminology and details on the various interfaces and tools available in radare2 Cutter.
radare2-cutter-part-1-key-terminology-an.shortdesc: An overview of some key terminology and the interfaces and tools in Cutter.
radare2-cutter-part-1-key-terminology-an.snippet: Cutter is an open-source graphical user interface for the radare2 reverse engineering framework. This article contains an introduction to reverse engineering with Cutter, including key terminology and an overview of the Cutter interface and available tools. Cutter can be found on GitHub here: https://github.com/radareorg/cutter

testing-your-csp-using-travis-ci-and-hea.title: Automatically Testing Your Content Security Policy Using Travis-CI and Headless Chrome Crawler
testing-your-csp-using-travis-ci-and-hea.longdesc: A Travis-CI build configuration for automatically testing your website's Content Security Policy.
testing-your-csp-using-travis-ci-and-hea.shortdesc: A Travis-CI build config for automatically testing your CSP.
testing-your-csp-using-travis-ci-and-hea.snippet: I have recently put together a Travis-CI build configuration that automatically tests your website for Content Security Policy violations. The configuration sets up a local copy of your site on a Travis-CI virtual machine with a CSP header set to send violation reports to a local reporting endpoint. The site is then crawled using Headless Chrome Crawler, which causes CSP violation reports to be generated where required. These are then displayed at the end of the build log.

launching-a-public-hackerone-program.title: Launching a Public HackerOne Security Vulnerability Disclosure Program
launching-a-public-hackerone-program.longdesc: A write-up of launching the public HackerOne security vulnerability disclosure program for JamieWeb.
launching-a-public-hackerone-program.shortdesc: A write-up of launching my HackerOne program.
launching-a-public-hackerone-program.snippet: Last month, I launched a public HackerOne security vulnerability disclosure program for my website. I've been working on this for a while, and I'm now very happy to have launched the program publicly! If you're a hacker and you'd like to have a go, the program is accessible on HackerOne here: https://hackerone.com/jamieweb

secure-public-wifi-access.title: Using a Public Wi-Fi Hotspot Securely
secure-public-wifi-access.longdesc: Connecting to hotel Wi-Fi through a Raspberry Pi and forwarding an external VPN connection.
secure-public-wifi-access.shortdesc: Connecting to hotel Wi-Fi through a Raspberry Pi and VPN.
secure-public-wifi-access.snippet: <u>The problem:</u> You want to connect to the internet in a hotel or coffee shop, but don't want to expose your laptop to the insecure, unencrypted Wi-Fi network. <u>A solution:</u> Connect to the internet through a Raspberry Pi, and have it forward a secure VPN connection through to your laptop.

letsencrypt-scts-in-certificates.title: Let's Encrypt SCTs in Certificates
letsencrypt-scts-in-certificates.longdesc: Let's Encrypt certificates now have Signed Certificate Timestamps (SCTs) included by default.
letsencrypt-scts-in-certificates.shortdesc: LE certificates now have embedded SCTs by default.
letsencrypt-scts-in-certificates.snippet: As of 29th March 2018, all certificates issued by Let's Encrypt now include a Signed Certificate Timestamp (SCT) embedded in the certificate in the form of an X.509 v3 extension.

disabling-tls1.0-tls1.1.title: Disabling TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1
disabling-tls1.0-tls1.1.longdesc: Assessing browser compatibility and disabling older TLS protocol versions.
disabling-tls1.0-tls1.1.shortdesc: Assessing browser compatibility and disabling older TLS protocol versions.
disabling-tls1.0-tls1.1.snippet: I recently received a security report to my HackerOne program from retr0, who suggested that I disable TLS 1.0 on my web server. At first I was reluctant as this breaks compatibility with many older browsers, however after monitoring the TLS protocol versions in use by users, I've now disabled both TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1, meaning that only TLS 1.2 can be used.
